GOVERNMENT CHINESE
SECONDARY IV EXAMINATION
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


2.31 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Yong, ministerial statement?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker. Sir, I am pleased to report to Members of this House that today, the last day of the first Government Secondary IV Examination in the Chinese medium, the highest number of candidates which sat for the examination so far was registered, namely, 1,958 out of a total of 3,169 candidates, of whom 2,956 were candidates from Chinese secondary schools and 213 were candidates from the Adult Education Board, that is, the Lembaga Gerakan Pelajaran Dewasa. This figure represents 62 per cent of the candidates taking the examination despite determined and concerted efforts

Column: 1054

by political agitators to boycott the examination through picketing and other methods of intimidation.

    I wish to pay the highest tribute - and so will all Members of this House and the people of Singapore who stand for law and order and for sanity - to the thousands of students and their parents who refused to be cowed by intimidation. I wish also to express my deepest gratitude and appreciation to all presiding officials, invigilators, principals, teachers and staff of schools, and the staff and officials of my Ministry for their unflinching loyalty in the cause of national education in the Chinese medium in the face of great provocation and intimidation that went on for the past five days.

    In view of the stress and strain to which candidates have been subjected as a result of the picketing of examination centres by those agitators who organised the boycotting of this examination, the marking of examination scripts will certainly take into consideration the psychological handicaps and the unfavourable conditions under which candidates answered the examination papers. Whenever necessary, the school records of candidates will also he taken into account.

    A supplementary examination in all subjects will be conducted next week, as announced yesterday, for all candidate who were prevented from sitting for any of the papers in the regular examination conducted this week. Candidates are, however, advised not to sit for papers next week for which they have already sat. Details of the supplementary examination are as follows:- 

       Centre 1 - Teachers' Training College, Paterson Road;

       

       Centre 2 - Tanglin Boys' School     }   Off Tanglin Road,

                                           }   behind the Ministry of Education, 

       Centre 3 - Tanglin Girls' School    }   Kay Siang Road.


    The time-table will follow the same order as the regular examination:

    Monday, 4th December, 1961:

    12.30 to 2.30 p.m. - Chemistry

    12.30 - 2.30 p.m. - Physics

    3 to 5 p.m. - General Science

    The Government Senior Middle III Examination, will be held as scheduled at 44 centres from Friday, 8th December, to Thursday, 14th December. There is no change in time-table or examination centres.

    As the Teachers' Training College will now be used as a centre for the supplementary examination of the Government Chinese Secondary IV Examination from 4th to 8th December, the T.T.C. Professional Part 1, Part II (all language media) and T.U.O.S. (Trained under other schemes) (all-years) examinations scheduled to be held from the week commencing Monday, 4th December, will have to be postponed for one week to Monday, 11th December, 1961. The detailed time-table arrangements from day to day will remain unchanged.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in accordance with the principle of equal treatment for the four language streams of education in Singapore, I am pleased to announce that those who pass the Government Secondary IV examination, in Chinese, will be eligible to apply for 100 bursaries, which will be tenable for two years in Upper Secondary classes, valued at $420 per annum. The award of bursaries will, as usual, be based on academic merit and financial need. This. Sir, is similar to the 100 bursaries now available to students in the English secondary schools who passed the Cambridge School Certificate Examination and are attending two

Column: 1056

years of upper secondary classes prior to taking the Cambridge Higher School Certificate Examination.

    It may be pertinent to ask, Mr Speaker, Sir, why this boycott has failed and why the evil men who tried to use misguided students as cover for their sinister and dangerous political operations have been reduced to a state of impotent frustration. The first reason is that the Government, in tackling this delicate issue, steadfastly refused to fall into the pro-Communist trap of hitting out at the misguided and excited student picketers in order to get at the manipulators who hid behind the students and who in their cowardly way used the bodies of school children as their shield. The second reason is that the stand of the Government on this issue was a just and sensible one. That being so, public opinion was on the side of the Government's stand which was that no one was compelled to take this examination. It is quite clear from what happened during the past one week that the vast majority of students wanted to take this examination. Despite intimidation by politically manipulated student picketers, more than half of the students braved the pickets to take the examination. If there had been no intimidation by hostile and unruly picketers, there is no doubt that the attendance would have been higher. This is shown by today's attendance. As the dispirited picketers melted away, more students turned up for the examination. The third reason why this boycott failed is that students and parents on their own initiative decided that they were not going to be cowed by the picketers and their cowardly leaders. Gone are the days when students and parents could be intimidated in this fashion. The moment students and parents decided to stand up to the picketers and to exercise their rights, the so-called boycott collapsed like a house of cards. This should be a good lesson to the pro-Communist conspirators that the days are gone when they could intimidate the people and bamboozle students and parents with false slogans.

Column: 1057



    The past week's events have shown clearly that there is no real foundation for the myth that Chinese schools are centres of unrest and indiscipline. Last week's events have proved that the vast majority of Chinese school students, like students in other language streams, are not only basically law-abiding and responsible, but will not hesitate to stand up bravely for what is right and fair, in standing up to the picketers, they were asserting their rights as students to take an examination which would not only equip them educationally but also enable them as educated citizens to contribute to the welfare and progress of our country.

    In today's Free Press there is a picture, Sir, of parents and supporters standing outside the Ministry of Education to protect students, who wish to sit for the examination, from the picketers. You will see, Sir, that unlike the picketers there are no handkerchiefs tied around their faces to hide their faces. This is because they have nothing to be ashamed of. There was no reason for these people to hide their faces from the people. But not so the picketers. They all had to hide behind handkerchiefs. They dared not reveal their true faces.

    The students who sat for the examination and who forced their way through booing and sometimes violent pickets are the kind of Malayans and citizens on whom we base our hopes for a peaceful, prosperous and happy Malaya. Contrast them with the misguided students who were tricked into picketing instead of taking the examination. They have wasted a year of study. They have got nothing out of the picketing and their leaders will not be able to make good this loss. These leaders will abandon these misguided students and seek fresh stooges and reckless adventures elsewhere.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I seek clarification on one point? May I ask the Minister the reason for the hurry in holding the supplementary examination on Monday,

Column: 1058

and whether it will not be better to hold it when conditions are more normal and tempers have subsided?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I think, Sir, it is necessary to carry on because the people have shown that they have fight in them and they can therefore proceed next week because the other Government Senior Middle III Examination will take place in any case from Friday. So whether there is tension or not, examinations will go on. The agitators behind this must realise that they are fighting not just the Government but the students, the parents and all the people of Singapore. And if they still continue to do so, it will be at their peril.

Column: 1058

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.48 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.".-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens of Merger Day".' -(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.50 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I gave a resume of

Column: 1059

the pre-war history and the post-war political developments of our fatherland. I also related briefly how the Communists and pro-Communists in Malaya manipulated, manoeuvred and posed themselves as true Malayan nationalists. Mr Speaker, Sir, at that time, the Malayan nationalist fighters were quite prepared to struggle in close co-operation with them so long as they did not infringe or transgress upon national interests.

    With reference to the amendment of the Member for Queenstown, I said yesterday that it has at least four veiled motives. It is evident that party interests and party ideology take first place, with the Communist back-room boys giving instructions. Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Barisan Sosialis and other political Parties having an identical political ideology are sincere in wanting a full and complete merger, why have the words "complete merger" not been inserted without the necessity to accentuate citizenship? In other words, a complete merger means the acceptance without qualification of the present policies of the Federation of Malaya on citizenship, education, labour, language and other matters. But this is not what they asked for. Their contention is that the rights and interests of the people of the Federation are our rights, but, that the rights and interests of the people of Singapore cannot be interfered with by the Federation. Surely, this is not the spirit of give and take, and it is unjust. Even small children understand this kind of arithmetical calculation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday the Member for Thomson - he is not here at the moment - posed at least 16 questions which he himself answered. The questions posed were why the people of Singapore could not get this and that and whether the Nanyang University diplomas will be recognised by the Federation of Malaya. All those questions are just like asking rights from the Federation of Malaya. This means that we are prepared to take but not to give.

Column: 1060



    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am a married man and my wife is my wife, of course; but if the wife of another person becomes my wife, this is not fair. If the Barisan Sosialis and other political Parties which share the views of the Barisan Sosialis are really sincere and responsible in their desire for merger, they must openly declare their acceptance of the present Federation Constitution - chapter and verse. They must also be prepared to give an undertaking to this Assembly and to all the people of Singapore that their stand is acceptable and that the people will be behind them, otherwise they should not try and hide behind a smokescreen or attempt to fish in troubled waters or try to poke at a hornet's nest.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, many of the points raised by the Member for Queenstown in support of his amendment have already been adequately dealt with by my colleagues, but all the same I wish to add a little here and there to give it a finishing touch, just like adding a little more spice to the gravy to make it more appetising. I will be brief, of course, and do not intend to beat the record of the speech of the Member for Queenstown.

    Mr Speaker, the Member for Queenstown was in a rage when he attempted to convince the House that he and his Party alone were the real saviours of Singapore. Let us look at the accusations that he hurled against the nationalist fighters, independence through merger, the tabling of the White Paper, and the motion under debate. He said that Singapore has been sold, that the Tunku wants Singapore but not her people and that when British colonialism goes out of the front door, another form of colonialism will enter from the back door. He equated Singapore to the position of a mistress, its people as second-class citizens, and many other hackneyed phrases such as those uttered by a prostitute to her lover or to the man who keeps her.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, to the linguist, it is evident that the language of the Member for Queenstown is, according to an old Malay adage, "As the tree, so the fruit." Language reflects the mind. Your

Column: 1061

demeanour reflects your character. Now, Mr Speaker, Sir, everything is clear to us. The evidence is as clear as daylight.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the basis of unity and solidarity of a nation is the devotion and undivided loyalty of its citizens to the State. The absence of these factors will result in the destruction of the State. "When a house is on fire, the rats run helter skelter," - so goes another Malay saying. Mr Speaker, Sir, therefore, undivided loyalty is one of the absolute prerequisites for a strong and united nation and State. Only by sacrifices can we prove our sincerity and loyalty to the State. Take an easy example - for the benefit of Members who claim themselves to be representatives of the Barisan Sosialis - the Russian Communist Party. Yuri Gagarin, the first cosmonaut, was accepted as a fully-fledged member of the Russian Communist Party only after his perilous performance of orbiting round the earth. This was a sacrifice. Mr Speaker, when I say that the basis of unity and strength of a nation rests on the undivided loyalty of the citizens, it does not imply that I am accusing the people of Singapore, whether in this House or outside, that they are disloyal to the State. That is not my intention at all, Mr Speaker.

    I was listening attentively to the greater part of the speeches made by the Opposition Members, particularly from the group of 13 who style themselves the Barisan Sosialis, and who have all the time been emphasising on automatic citizenship.

    I believe, Mr Speaker, that there is no one in this Assembly who will not agree to automatic citizenship if the Federation Government is willing to accept this. The Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tunku Abdul Rahman, rejected this demand, as contained in his communication dated 13th November, 1961, to the Singapore Prime Minister, and circulated to all Members. The decision of the Tunku, according to his letter rejecting this demand, clearly reflects the view of the people of the Federation of Malaya. This

Column: 1062

view is based on the Federation Constitution, although Article 22 of the Constitution states that Parliament can decide and determine the rights of the people of a new State on joining the Federation. But can this demand he acceptable to the Members of Parliament in the Federation? The views of the Prime Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman, represent the stand of his Government and the Alliance Party, which is now in power.

    If this motion were moved in Parliament, I am sure the Pan-Malayan Islamic Party would rise in strong opposition. There may be a handful of men who will support the demand of the Barisan Sosialis in Singapore

    - people like Mr D. R. Seenivasagam, Mr Lim Kean Siew, and a few other puppets, representing only a small minority in the Parliament. In facing a national issue that involves a multi-racial society like Singapore, we must attempt to resolve it in a spirit of sincerity and compromise which will riot adversely affect the interests of any particular section in the community. In order to prove and demonstrate our loyalty to the State, we should be prepared to make sacrifices. There is no struggle that does not call for sacrifice. We must study the historical background of our fatherland, and we should accordingly be guided in our struggle to achieve national objectives.

    Mr Speaker, we should not allow ourselves to be carried away by sentiments, because this will be detrimental to our national unity, which has been developed by our nationalist heroes who have sacrificed their all and who have undergone repressive and oppressive treatment in the past. Mr Speaker, no struggle will be achieved in one day, just as Rome was not built in a day. Therefore, we, as leaders of a nation, fighters of the State, must have cool minds and seek all avenues of approach in order to resolve our difficulties. In this way we can demonstrate to the people that we are citizens with an undivided loyalty to the State and thereby convince our brothers in the Federation that we are truly their brethren of the same nation and enjoying

Column: 1063

the same fate. To true Malayan nationalists or to the self-proclaimed leaders, this should be the first task which they must discharge. To be overcome by political sentiments and party ideologies in order to win the support of the people will not solve our national problems.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, to those who allege that Singapore has been sold to the Federation, or that Singapore will he colonised by Malaya, or that Singapore will become another Manchuria, I say categorically and in all frankness that such people are insincere and that they do not regard Malaya as the object of their sole and undivided loyalty. I wish to repeat this, Mr Speaker - such people are insincere and they do not regard Malaya as the object of their sole and undivided loyalty. My charge is justified, Mr Speaker, for we are all agreed unanimously that Malaya and Singapore are one, that is to say, one country. We are in the process of building a united Malayan nation. Therefore, those who regard themselves as aliens or regard Singapore as an alien country clearly consider themselves un-Malayans. It is impossible for a nation to colonise its own people. The people in Malaya are all our brothers, of the same kind and enjoying the same fate. The same can he said for those who refuse to acknowledge Singapore as being a part of the Federation of Malaya. If Formosa reverts to the mainland of China, does it mean that the Republic of China is colonising Formosa or Taiwan? It is a different case if the Americans go to Formosa or Taiwan. But if Formosa reverts to Communist China, to me it is not a form of colonisation. If they really contend that Singapore forms part of the Federation of Malaya and that we belong to the same nation and are known as the people of Malaya, then there is nothing to fear. I feel the debate in this Assembly would have taken the form of a more sincere and sober note, and such diatribes as "to colonise", "sell-out", "Manchurian incident", or what have you, would not have been uttered in this Assembly by people with any sense of decency at all towards their brothers in the Federation of Malaya.

Column: 1064



    Mr Speaker, of course, we can discuss our rights and our grievances. Or we can even ask for complete merger and so on. This is in the true spirit of democratic practice. But to indulge in such vituperation will certainly result in explosive consequences detrimental to our efforts to bring about unity to our people, and to create a united Malayan nation in our multi-racial society.

    Mr Speaker, I sincerely exhort and appeal from the bottom of my heart to all those who have found themselves astray at the end of the road to go back to the start so that they may not get completely lost altogether. The allegation that the Singapore Prime Minister has succeeded in persuading and convincing the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya with frightening stories is, I believe, tantamount to ridiculing a Government which was elected by the people. It is also an insult to the people of Malaya, who have elected their Prime Minister, that their Prime Minister can easily be influenced by the Prime Minister of Singapore. I am saying this in the interest of unity of both the peoples of the two territories. There are people who say that this merger proposal was not written in the P.A.P. Five-Year Plan and so why must merger be accelerated? Does it mean that we shall have to wait? May I ask; until Mr D. R. Seenivasagam, or Mr Lim Kean Siew, or even the stooges, or even the Malayan Communist Party, hold the reins of the Federation government, who can achieve merger before us? Answer yourself.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the challenge that general elections should be held both in Singapore and in the Federation, I feel that as regards Singapore the challenge has already been answered but I will further answer it later on. With regard to the Federation, let the people of the Federation themselves give the answer. It is hardly becoming of us if we in Singapore, as one of the twelve States of the Federation, were to demand our brothers in the other eleven States to obey our beckoning. This is yet another instance of the Barisan's own vileness.

Column: 1065



    The Member for Queenstown has posed this question: "Has our Prime Minister carried the fight for an equality of status for the people of Singapore into the Federation Parliament?" I feel this question is like the nightmare of a person who is sleeping during the day. We are not as yet merged with the Federation. We have no representatives in the Federation Parliament to voice our demands. Tarry a while until the time when we can send our representatives to the Federal Parliament when merger has taken place. In the meantime, I wonder whether the Barisan Sosialis already have their representatives or agents in the Federation Parliament, in the persons of Mr Lim Kean Siew and Mr D. R. Seenivasagam, to put forward their demands. That I would not like to say.

    Mr Speaker, with regard to "merger", several Members of the Assembly have given various definitions. There are those who say that merger is like a marriage. But there are different kinds of marriages. I am not a doctor of matrimony, Mr Speaker, Sir, and perhaps that is why I find it somewhat perplexings to grasp this analogy. If the analogy of matrimony is advanced, I say surely you would not expect to beget yourself a child on the morrow of your wedding day. Unless, of course, there are other ways of begetting legal children! I am not a doctor like the Member for Nee Soon. For me, Mr Speaker, I would draw the analogy of a big river with twelve minor tributaries. Eleven of these tributaries have been freed of obstruction and have joined the main river. But one of these tributaries has had a harrier placed at its confluence, so that its water is not free to flow out into the main river. When the harrier at the confluence is removed, the water will be able to flow freely to join the main river. However, upon so doing, the water from the tributary will not automatically change its characteristic. That is to say, its taste, its colour, and so on, will not be identical with those of the water in the main river. It is only after it has undergone several phases of

Column: 1066

the tide that its identity will be completely merged with that of the rest, in the fullest sense of the word.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if there is anyone whose thinking is confused and whose stand is wavering and uncertain, that person is the Member for Cairnhill. There was a time when he would thump his chest and proudly exclaim that only his Party could bring about merger with the Federation of Malaya. But now the hollowness of his words are only too obvious. Nevertheless, the Member for Cairnhill has other excuses to put forward to explain why he cannot concede that the basic agreements as contained in the White Paper do, in fact, constitute merger between Singapore and the Federation of Malaya.

    Mr Speaker, he merely depends on the newspapers. But he did not take into consideration the paper-work that has been going on. We have not forgotten yet, Mr Speaker, that the Secretary-General of the S.P.A., Mr Lim Choon Mong, who was also probably an adviser to the Member for Cairnhill, and sometime ago that only the S.P.A. could succeed in bringing about merger.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I wonder how all this is relevant to the amendment. All that the hon. Member is saying is, probably the Member for Cairnhill and his Party failed to obtain merger. Where is the relevance to the amendment?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): I feel, Mr Speaker, that we are now on the question of merger, and I am replying to the arguments that have been put forward by the Member for Cairnhill, who is a representative of his Party in the Assembly. Therefore, I was touching on his stand and that of his Party on the question of merger which we are now debating in this Assembly. But, Mr Speaker, what can the Member for Cairnhill say now? He can only say, "If the S.P.A. were in power, we too would be able to achieve what is contained in the White Paper, or even more." As the Malay saying has it. "When the house is completed, the chisel is heard. When the matter is settled, you put in your word."

Column: 1067



    Mr Speaker, I do not wish to speak a great deal about the Member for Cairnhill. It appears to me that the demeanour of the Member for Anson is no different. Intentionally or unintentionally, he has been defending his clients from the Barisan Sosialis who, according to him, are in a pitiable state as the Barisan Sosialis have no legal adviser in this House. But the Member for Anson is forgetting that they have many advisers waiting outside this Assembly. According to the Member for Anson, the amendment proposed by the Member for Queenstown is to make the definition of "merger" more complete. What is surprising is this. Why should citizenship alone complete the definition of merger? Why not say, "Full merger", which by itself embraces the question of citizenship, education, language, culture, internal security, etc.?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, what is even more surprising is that he and his own Party have not yet decided on a clear stand on the question of merger. In his speech last Thursday, he showed his considerable skill at staking his bets. His habit is to have a stake on all sides so that he will not be a loser. If there are four digits, he will lay his stake on all the four digits so that whichever way it goes, he will not be the loser. So also is his strategem in politics. He wants merger with the Federation. He also desires independence for Singapore. He welcomes full internal self-government. He also welcomes an international status for Singapore with the State being placed under the protection of the United Nations. Indeed, he will even countenance Singapore deteriorating into another Congo.

    In his speech last week, he showed his true form once again. He said, "Curse the Communists!" He also said, "Beware of the Members of the Barisan Sosialis, who are pro-Communists, and beware of their intelligentsia. Then he went on to say. "Tunku Abdul Rahman is a foremost statesman, sincere and honest." But he did not admit to having played up the theme of Communism. "Support the special rights of the Malays." he said. In the same breath, he said, "Cursed be those who say only the

Column: 1068

Chinese are Communists." Thus, where does he stand, Mr Speaker? He is here, and he is there, so that he is loaded with stands which are all calculated to be to his good. This is the demeanour and disposition of a Member who brings a hammer into this House. Whom does he want to scare and hammer, Mr Speaker?
